Title: The Most Rewatchable Hard-to-Watch Movie Ever!
Review:
A film shot in a documentary style can be wrenching and brutal, but can it also be as poignant and touching as usual great drama films? Yes, Spielberg proved this is very possible! I was overwhelmed with all different feelings throughout its 3 hours and 15 minutes runtime. This movie's catharsis is even may be stronger than any movie I've watched in my life!

Neeson's performance as Oskar Schindler is easily his best performance ever. He brought his character to life which is already can be top any list for top 10 most complex and compelling characters in film.

Schindler's List is undoubtedly a masterpiece, and easily one of, if not the best Spielberg's films, and its greatness made it the most rewatchable hard-to-watch movie ever!

(10/10)

Title: A review from 2018 - moving all the way through
Review:
This is actually my first review on IMDB, and I would be the last to expect it being written about a black and white movie from 1993. This probably says a little about my prejudice on "old" movies in black and white. That said.

Some here believe Schindlers List is way too long a movie and dull. Over rated. I beg to differ. The fact that the movie is black and white does not bother me. You notice it in the beginning, but you quickly get used to it. As Ben Kingsley in the role of Itzhak Stern says; the movie is filmed in a way that seems to capture it as if it were filmed right there in 1940.

Another remark I would like to make in the beginning, is that my class, a bunch of 13-year olds, watched this film at school. I thought it was way too long, boring, and ugh, in black and white. I got the impression most of my classmates thought the same. Based on this experience, and that I just yesterday, at the age of 25, watched the movie again, I would say most teenagers (12-15) won't enjoy the movie as it should be enjoyed.

Since this is my first review it's probably too long and incoherent. I apologise. Steven Spielberg's story telling is capturing. Not for one moment did I expect or wish that the movie would come to an end. I am especially impressed by Liam Neeson and Ben Kingsley - although that is evident, and predictable, should you watch the movie and enjoy it.

As a true movie fan and lover, I would say it in this simple way - the movie kept me watching to the end with a mix of horror an awe - and although most of this was sad and gruesome - the ending made me cry.

I have, admittedly, had a fascination for the holocaust and WW2 the last week, something that maybe makes me biased. Going into watching this, I thought; this is a movie from 1993, in black and white. Also a very delicate subject is being presented here, which maybe makes the movie "good" in a sense because the story and reality of the events is so realistic. I can only conlude that this is a very good film.

Title: Heartbreaking and Heartwarming, an Essential Film for All Humans
Review:
"Schindler's List" is a movie that both shows us the best and the worst of humanity. It's an enthralling work of cinematic mastery, and I think that it is a film that every human being should watch. That's not hyperbole or exaggeration. The atrocity that the Nazi regime committed against the Jewish population will always be remembered as one of the most despicable acts of history. But the film is more than scenes of brutality. We are also shown that trauma and war can often bring out the most brave and heroic actions.

The film focuses on the actions of Oskar Schindler, played brilliantly by Liam Neeson. Schindler runs a factory that makes pots and pans, and he is initially very cozy and close with high ranking members of the Nazi Party. Through bribes and lavish parties, Schindler is able to gain a tremendous amount of political power and he is also able to secure a source of free labor: recently displaced Jews who now live in the cramped ghettoes of Krak√≥w, Poland. Schindler is assisted by Itzhak Stern (Ben Kingsley), a Jewish accountant who manages the financials of Schindler's factory. After a period of comfort and stability, Amon G√∂th (Ralph Fiennes) takes charge as the new commandant of Krak√≥w. G√∂th orders the liquidation of the ghetto and the subsequent transplant of the Jews to the nearby Plasz√≥w concentration camp. The rest of the film involves Schindler's shift from a greedy factory runner to becoming more and more empathetic of the Jewish strife. Schindler's character arc is placed opposite G√∂th's unchanging brutality and psychopathic fits of rage.

There is lots of symbolism to behold in this movie. Some are more obvious, such as the girl in the red dress and the candles. But I think just the contrast between Schindler's and G√∂th's differing aspects of man's treatment of fellow man is what elevates this film and moves me, personally. There are many examples within the film, scenes with Schindler and G√∂th played back to back where we see their reactions to events play out in starkly different ways. You could really tell this kind of a story in a variety of different settings, but the Holocaust is definitely one that hits many emotional chords.

On top of it being one of the best depictions of the Holocaust in cinematic history, the deeply layered thematic storytelling, as well as top-notch acting, cinematography, and direction from the venerable Steven Spielberg, "Schindler's List" is certainly one of the greatest films of all time. It's not a film that you watch for entertainment, it is one to be cherished as a work of art, and as one that will educate and move future generations to never forget our past, both the courageous and the depraved.

Title: A Horrific, Depressing, Honest yet also an Occasionally Hopeful and Beautiful Film from Steven Spielberg
Review: Schindler's List is long, depressing, horrific and is in no means an easy film to watch but I personally believe all humans need to watch it to have a greater insight on the atrocity that was the Holocaust. The film has incredible acting with Liam Neeson giving the best performance of his career as Oskar Schindler the first flawed then latter redeemed protagonist of the film, not to mention Ben Kinglsley as Itzhak Stern and Ralph Fiennes as the horrific, evil and vile yet also human Amon Goeth the ruthless Nazi commandant of the Krakow-Plaszow concentration camp. The use of black and white is extremely well used by Spielberg giving the visuals a blunt almost nonchalant feeling of honesty about the events unfolding. But what is truly special is how he uses a small amount of color at certain moments in the film, like for instance the little girl in the red coat, that adds to the emotions being felt onscreen. Schindler's List is also incredibly tense at times. The threat of the Jewish characters being killed is constantly lingering with some scenes like the showers in Auschwitz and a worker being taken out back of the factory being unbearable to watch at times. But with all the horrible inhuman actions happening, the film also is quiet beautiful and hopeful and heartwarming towards the end that is sure to leave most audience members weeping. Schindler's List is a haunting film that will leave you emotionally broken by the end of it but will give you a greater insight and understanding of the truly inhuman acts committed during the holocaust that is important for all people to recognize and come to terms with.

Title: My favorite movie from Steven Spielberg
Review: If I really had to pick a problem, I'd say the first hour of the movie, while not terrible at all, felt a little bit underwhelming. It was still shot brilliantly, edited brilliantly, acted well and was still visually stunning. But I felt like it was not fully giving the gothic and horrifying imagery that I thought I was going to get. Only one man is shot from what I remember in the first hour. But the film immediately gets better when Ralph Fiennes appears as Amon Goth. Fiennes gives a horrifying and powerful performance and makes the film become a 10/10. The gothic imagery also becomes horrifying and heartbreaking to watch. It also has much better pacing, writing and also establishes a horrifying and gothic atmosphere that makes it so good. The acting from everyone is out of this world. Liam Neeson is absolutely phenomenal as the titular Oskar Schindler and gives a powerful and heartbreaking performance. Fiennes as I said earlier becomes a god-send to a first act and immediately makes the movie better because of his performance and the intimidation he gives in the way he portrays Goth. Ben Kingsley gives a fantastic performance as well knowing how to portray a person who is willing to help a man who works for the Nazi party who turns into a good person. But knows without him he'll probably be killed by the Nazis. The cinematography and editing are absolutely phenomenal forming a documentary style of the movie that in some ways is similar to the 1975 film Shoah which really fits the tone of the movie. The music is also phenomenal. I mean it's John Williams and he almost always does a perfect job establishing the film's tone and style of the film. With a gorgeous main theme to establish the heartbreaking and horrifying scenes you'll see later. Seeing the corpses of the Jewish people being burned is extremely heartbreaking to watch. I can see why this is one of the greatest films of all time because of the cinematography, editing, the performances, Spielberg's direction, the visuals, the themes, the messages, the music, the sound design, the writing, the tone, the style and the atmosphere of the film.

Title: I'm sorry, but it's awful
Review:
I don't know what to say about this movie. I had never seen it, so when I received it this spring I was eager to watch it. I find the subject of the Holocaust to be fascinating (not in a good way) because it's just astounding that this actually happened. It baffles the mind how this could occur on such a grand scale. I'm always watching shows on the history channel about WWII and the Holocaust and so I had very high expectations for this movie. So, I put it in my DVD player and sat down to watch a movie about a subject that I have a lot of interest in. Three hours later I felt as if every ounce of life had been sucked from my body. I was bored to death. I could never get emotionally attached to anyone in the movie. I know this sounds bad but I never felt sorry for anyone in this film. This film felt like it had no real vision or direction and it never bothered to develop any characters; everyone in the movie came across as wooden figures to me.

Now comes the real question; should a person watch a movie about the Holocaust expecting to be entertained? Well, the answer to this question is both yes and no. You shouldn't be entertained because it covers such a dark subject but anyone who enjoys history could be entertained because it covers significant event in human history. This where the film fails. It covers the event but it doesn't attempt to make the movie interesting, Spielberg must of decided that the subject matter alone was interesting enough and left it at that.

I can watch a show about the Holocaust on the history channel and I will be more emotionally attached to the people in that one hour show than I will be to anyone in that three hour boring film, Schlinder's List. I'm sorry but that's poor execution on Spielberg's part.

Title: Spielberg's best.
Review:
Schindler's List.

In German-occupied Poland during World War II, industrialist Oskar Schindler gradually becomes concerned for his Jewish workforce after witnessing their persecution by the Nazis.

Schindler's list is one of the best drama movies and biopics I've ever seen, undoubtedly it is a strong one that tries to show the suffer of the Jews in Poland back to the world war II, it's not the only movie that covers this matter, I've watched The Pianist the thing that made me appreciate more and more this masterpiece, you can see clearly that Spielberg's movie inspired the other one .

I haven't seen a lot of Spielberg's work but he's definitely one of the best actif and living directors, one of the directors who worked a lot through different generations...

This movie wouldn't be that great without Liam Neeson who made a great performance, probably his best as I need to mention that Ralph Fiennes did a wonderful job too.

The cinematography and using the black and white was very successful, serving the plot and time era, besides I really loved the soundtracks in this movie.

Title: Overrated title in my opinion.
Review:
The black and white film was a poor choice that eliminated the potential for any visual mastery since Spielberg isn't very good with black and white filming. There simply isn't any beautiful imagery or camera work in this film, a lot of intense set pieces (luggage stacked up, etc) but the camera glides by real quick in a hurry. It's a strange choice not to loom over the set a little longer, considering it is a 3 hour long picture.

In the end it is very boring. The first hurdle is the acting level, Leem Neeson just isn't very good. Then this is emphasized by the poor accent from Ralph Finnes, the conversations between the two come across very poorly rehearsed and amateurish.

What echoes the filming quality and acting quality is nearly all the scenes with extras, all seeming to be amateurs and not actors with any chops at all. I saw straight through it all, in some scenes the extras are smiling. This is supposed two be the persecution of the Jewish people from the Nazis... Why the heck are people smiling without any context? Also if they are not smiling they are just normal faced, not distressed, angry, confused, in pain or otherwise.

This is mirrored by the one dimensional antagonist, who spends nearly every second on film shooting random Jews. It is extremely contrived and I don't believe a single frame of it. This is poorly researched crap made into popcorn material for the sake of pulling emotional strings. Well, it didn't work on me.

If you want to see some real mastery and horror shown in this topic then I recommend 'Conspiracy', A HBO for TV movie on a secret meeting that pushes forward the plans for the death trains and concentration death camps... that will blow you away. Failing this, I would recommend Band of Brothers, a ten part mini series that covers american soldiers going to the front lines in WW2.

I give this a 5/10 as an average film. Usually this rating and below I give to films I would never watch again, including this one.

Title: If all but a few movies are erased from human memory, let Schindler's List be one that remains.
Review:
Schindler's List is simply Steven Spielberg's greatest movie. I dare you to challenge this. Sure, ET is great, and so is Jurassic Park, and so forth. But out of all the movies that Spielberg has directed, how can any of them top the power and importance of this one?

Schindler's List tells the true story of Oskar Schindler, portrayed wonderfully by Liam Neeson. He is a German who saved the lives of over 1,100 Jews during the Holocaust. Schindler does this out of greed, making them low wage workers in his factory for his benefit, but he later does it out of compassion for his fellow man.

That's the theme of the movie that echoes throughout long after the credits roll, and this is where the film's power stems from. The Nazis considered Jews to be "vermin" and not humans worthy of love, care, or compassion. Oskar Schindler over time sees that they ARE in fact worthy, and uses this basic human value to change the world.

Steven Spielberg waited over a decade to make this movie, because even though he wanted to do it after making E. T., he felt that he wasn't ready to tackle the Holocaust yet. (Note that Spielberg himself is Jewish.)

The time he took is well worth it, since he crafted the movie so well. Using beautiful black and white cinematography, he makes this tragic event come alive to those who were not there to see the unspeakable event.

Since this movie is centered around the greatest tragedy in all of human history, the film gains an R Rating for it's realistic violence. Prepare for Jews to be shot, burned, or gassed for what they believe in. It's hard to watch, but it's the most effective quality. There were people who took pleasure in killing millions of their own kind, and Spielberg exposes this horror to perfection.

This shows how Schindler's List won 7 Oscars, including Steven's sole Best Picture win and his first of 2 Best Director wins(the other being for Saving Private Ryan). All 7 are well earned for this fantastic movie.

I first saw this in 10th grade in History class, so I was 16. I would say 15 or 16 would be the best age to see this, and I say that because while everyone should see Schindler's List, it is not for the young, and historical prior knowledge is necessary.

Aside from the flaw of crimes against humanity, my only critique of Schindler's List is that the German accents of Non-German actors are so thick that I needed subtitles to follow the dialogue. Apart from this, Schindler's List is nothing short of a masterpiece.

Despite it's grim subject matter, Schindler's List must be seen, even if just once. Thank you, Oskar Schindler for your heroic act, and thank you Steven Spielberg for telling us his incredible story. By doing so, you have given us the best movie about the Holocaust ever made.

This is a powerful film that will leave a great impact on you. It should never be forgotten. If all but a few movies are erased from human memory, let Schindler's List be one that remains.

It took the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and the US Fleet to awaken them, but how do you tell millions of Jews including so many, many children that only the Japanese attack was important enough for America to enter the war.

Title: Humanity's Worst and Best displayed in a Single Film..
Review:
The genocide of Jews in Second World War has been portrayed on screen time and again, but none has been as widely recognized and praised as Steven Spielberg's Iconic Film centering on an opportunistic, womanizer, war profiteer who became World's Greatest Humanitarian. The carefully constructed plan of Nazis to ostracize the thriving, affluent community of Jews, throwing them into slums, and dehumanizing them to such a horrifying extent, that at the end they are herded like mere sheeps for slaughter in the Concentration camps. The horrifying scenes stick in your brain, and with John Williams' iconic score your heart bleeds again and again. Brilliant performances from Liam Neeson and Ben Kingsley elevate this film and especially Ralph Fiennes' Aemon Goeth, is a character that exudes such rare kind of evil, it will send chills down your spine. This landmark film needs to be seen by everyone to understand what evil humans are capable of unleashing, and how humans no matter how many faults they have, can stand up for whats right.

Title: Everyone should watch this film
Review: This is almost certainly the finest film I have seen to date, with Saving Private Ryan, another Spielberg film coming a fairly close second. Everything about this film is designed to try and raise awareness of actual events in their gruesome detail. Spielberg should be credited for using moderation to get the message across. There are scenes of violence, but overall the film is all the more effective for the implication of what is to come. Fiennes is chilling as the camp commandant, doubly so when you realise that this was an actual person who actually did the things shown, and all this less than a lifetime ago. Cinematography was superb throughout, and the brave decision to shoot in black and white adds to the authentic feel of the film. The final scenes are particularly emotional, and many people in the cinema were crying at the end. This film should be required viewing for any holocaust denier types, or just to those who have no concept of how evil men can be to their fellow man. Many people in Germany were left shocked after watching this film, because it's not the sort of thing that is discussed in depth over there (according to my German friend). 10/10

Title: A powerful, moving masterpiece. The most meaningful and emotional film ever made.
Review:
Steven Spielberg's Schindler's List is a reflection on how great this director is. His 3-hour painting of Oskar Schindler and his forever changing view on the Nazi rampage against the innocent Jews is simply the greatest film achievement since the simple secret of Citizen Kane is finally revealed in a magnificent, grand and intelligent way. The final scene in which a marching group of 11,000 or so saved Jews morph into real survivors (an in color vision) and the ceremonial funeral of Oskar Schindler showing the several survivors of the Schindler factory is a real marvel and a sign that box office king Steven Spielberg doesn't work just for money. Spielberg should be knighted or something for this movie, just like Schindler saved the Jews Spielberg let the Jews' pain and suffering be recognised and World War II be looked at beyond the view of the British and American army.

Title: Schindler's List
Review:
Short and Simple Review by WubsTheFadger

Schindler's List tells the story of Oscar Schindler as he says many Jews during World War II. The story is one that leaves you stunned. It is saddening, disturbing, and painful. The horrors of World War II and the brutality of the Nazi party are all clearly seen. The characters are powerfully portrayed and the ending is saddening yet hopeful.

The acting is sublime. Liam Neeson gives his best performance ever as Oscar Schindler. Ralph Fiennes also performs extremely well as a despicable and detestable Nazi commander. All of the supporting actors and actresses perform very well.

The pacing is slow and the runtime is overlong but Spielberg directs the film with great respect for the victims of this horrible tragedy.

Pros: Saddening, disturbing, and painful story, very deep characters, sublime acting, amazing performance by Liam Leeson and Ralph Fiennes, and great directing by Spielberg

Cons: Some slow pacing and an overlong runtime

Overall Rating: 9.0

Title: Love Time!
Review:
In Krak√≥w during World War II, the Germans have forced local Polish Jews into the overcrowded Krak√≥w Ghetto. Oskar Schindler, an ethnic German from Czechoslovakia, arrives in the city hoping to make his fortune. A member of the Nazi Party, Schindler lavishes bribes on Wehrmacht (German armed forces) and SS officials and acquires a factory to produce enamelware. To help him run the business, Schindler enlists the aid of Itzhak Stern, a local Jewish official who has contacts with black marketeers and the Jewish business community. Stern helps Schindler arrange financing for the factory. Schindler maintains friendly relations with the Nazis and enjoys wealth and status as "Herr Direktor", and Stern handles administration. Schindler hires Jewish workers because they cost less, while Stern ensures that as many people as possible are deemed essential to the German war effort, which saves them from being transported to concentration camps or killed.

Title: Great movie about a terrible plan
Review:
Long, and black and white. The only two knocks against an otherwise riveting representation of the Holocaust. I feel strange reting this film, as it feels more documentary than entertainment and my heart goes out to all six million casualties and also the survivors. Spielberg makes a really good effort to capture the emotional turmoil that only the people involved could truly feel during such an atrocious event in history.

Three main characters dominate the film. Let's start with Izthak Stern, the jew who works as Mr. Schindler's accountant, and also who works for Amon Goeth. Those are the three main characters. Ben Kingsley does a phenomenal job playing Stern and encapsulates an intelligent man who is always rightfully fearing death around every corner. He has information and basically knows all that goes on from both sides. His realism and sometimes sarcasm in the face of tragedy is great. He also feels like Mr. Schindler's psychologist on occasion as he listens to his plots, both the real ideas and the ones to be employed as deceit to get people out.

Amon Goeth is played well by Ralph Fiennes. By "well" i mean a murderous nazi leader who kills rampantly and truly does a good job portraying what i'd say is a pure hatred for jews and has no real empathy for the prisoners. True blank stares and evil psychopathic behavior are maybe adjectives a bit short of experiencing his lack of respect for human life.

And then there is Oskar Schindler. A nazi leader himself, this businessman might be perceived as a slick rich capitalist businessman and cheating husband because he is those things. But this IS the Holocaust and in light of that tragedy, this man uses his wealth to procure human life and preserve a small portion of the prisoner population. The juxtapostion of him and Goeth, though they are side by side quite often, makes him the quintessential hero of the day. He deserves that title.

All and all a really great depiction of something very hard to depict at all. All three of the above actors do a great job and worth a viewing for anyone who wants a glimpse onto Nazi Germany during WWII.

Title: Dull and too long
Review: Movies and documentaries about Holocaust are necessary to show people how hate and fear can turn human beings into monstrous beings but I rarely see those movies speaking about gypsies, homosexuals, disabled, mentally ill and other minorities who were also treated in a very inhumane way. In general, those stories lack something showing people how every human being must be treated with respect and dignity because, as another user said, people seem to be interested only in their cause, even if their neighbor's pain is similar to their own (in this case discrimination). Disliking such a movie apparently makes one automatically a bad person, but portraying arabians as terrorists seems to be fine for many, and implying gypsies and bad and dishonest as well. The same people who will reprimand you for disliking Schindler's List are the ones who think it's ok to hate on fats, homosexuals, the disabled. They are the same ones who think the mentally ill are just weak minded, the victims or rape brought it to themselves or the poor are lazy or undeserving of a better life. Society needs movies telling all types of stories about discriminated communities, individuals and ethnicities. The fact that the same person capable of great gratuitous dislike towards one person and great empathy towards another tells that we are missing a link that shows how every person should be treated with respect and not only one group.

Title: Be prepared to be moved to tears
Review:
"Schindler's List" is a deeply impactful film that takes you on an emotional journey from start to finish. At first glance, it may not appear particularly special, but as the story unfolds, it gradually reveals its true power. Director Steven Spielberg's masterful storytelling and the exceptional performances of the cast make this a truly unforgettable cinematic experience.

The film tells the true story of Oskar Schindler (Liam Neeson), a German businessman who saves the lives of over a thousand Jewish people during the Holocaust. It expertly depicts the horrors of the era, showcasing the unimaginable suffering endured by the victims. The gradual transformation of Schindler from a profit-driven opportunist to a compassionate savior is both inspiring and heartbreaking.

As the narrative progresses, the emotional weight of the story intensifies, culminating in a profoundly moving ending. It's during this climax that the film truly shines, leaving a lasting impact that lingers in your mind and heart long after the credits roll. The combination of John Williams' haunting score and the heartbreaking performances of the cast creates an atmosphere that evokes genuine emotions, often leading to tears.

"Schindler's List" is not an easy film to watch, but its importance cannot be overstated. It serves as a powerful reminder of the atrocities of the Holocaust and the resilience of the human spirit. This film is a testament to the indomitable strength of those who survived and the importance of standing up against injustice.

Title: a must-see film!
Review:

This film is a great example of how screenplay, film direction, acting, and cinematography can collectively tell a vivid story, even for sensitive and controversial ones such as the events of the Holocaust. Its success as a film is one of the many ways this conversation is kept alive- fostering and encouraging empathy and compassion for others in generations to come.

Title: Wonderfully made film, but very flawed.............
Review: The problem with 'Schindler's List' is that, although superbly made by one of the most talented directors who ever lived, it has an agenda: to convince people of the Holocaust. I mean, why add all those dramatic scenes of children being led to their deaths, the gassings, bodies burning etc? What did all that add to the film story apart from try to shock the viewers? Schindler himself was, in reality, far removed from the nice man portrayed by Liam Neeson. Most of what he did was not because he particularly cared about the Jews, but because they made him lots of money. He was also a serial womaniser and adulterer. Basically, the film is a sentimental Hollywood melodrama which happens to be set at a time of great cruelty, motivated by blind fanaticism. An opportunity was lost to analyse WHY the Nazis hated Jews so much, what were the fundamental roots of the German-Jewish conflict? Instead Spielberg went for the safe option of creating brutal German robots and innocent, perplexed Jewish victims. And the final scene when Schindler gave his speech was frankly ridiculous. Final verdict: magnificent film, subject matter not properly presented.

Title: See "Judgment at Nuremberg" instead.
Review:
In one of the final scenes of "Schindler's List," which may serve as a microcosm of this terribly flawed movie, a camp inmate is depicted as being so grateful to his kindly and charitable Nazi liberator that with his own hand he removes a gold tooth from his own mouth and gratefully hands it to the Nazi as a gift. Allowing that such a thing may actually have taken place, still I believe one is entitled to question the artistic judgment the director exercised in showing it. Surely Mr. Spielberg has seen the film "Judgment at Nuremberg" and knows that among the damning evidence presented by the United States Army War Tribunal against Nazi war criminals were gold teeth that were forcibly removed from the mouths of inmates and kept as booty by the thugs who ran the camps. In the wake of the war crimes trials, the extracted gold tooth became one of the main icons or symbols of the horrible wrongs perpetrated against the Jews by the Nazis. What kind of a sick joke is it to show a camp inmate voluntarily extracting his own gold tooth, when it is very well known that it was usually either Nazi camp guards or "sonderkommandos" (camp inmates who turned traitor) who forcibly performed the extractions, sometimes before the victim was even put to death?

The entire movie is defective in my opinion, because it conveys the idea that there was significant Nazi sympathy for concentration camp inmates. For a generation of film-goer who did not live through World War II and who were born decades later, this film may be the only one they'll see on the subject of concentration camps and the Nazis. Many of the audience probably left the theaters after seeing this film with the false impression that it wasn't so bad in the forced labor camps because the guys running them were sympathetic, charitably minded human beings. In fact, most Nazis who had anything to do with the camps or forced labor were the worst sort of subhuman vermin (they were called the "scum of Europe" at the time). What purpose does it serve to depict any Nazi with control over concentration camp inmates as a philanthropist, with a charming romantic passion for his imprisoned slaves?

As a rule, any so-called historical truth is open to question and doubt, never more so in a movie than here. Although the facts in "Schindler's List" are generally accepted by film-goers and critics alike (according to the press), can we be absolutely sure they are true, when everything else we know about the subject runs 180 degrees in the opposite direction? Just because a work has been published or produced doesn't make it true. Many historical accounts have been proved wrong in spirit and in fact.

The danger of any movie that treats controversial and ethically difficult historical subject matter is that it is likely to be regarded as a universal truth about the period instead of as a particular story. So I don't regard this movie as true history, because it is misleading as a generalization. And possibly some or all of the relevant "facts" presented are false or distorted. I recommend to anyone who does not want to be misled about the holocaust that they see "Judgment at Nuremberg" instead!

Title: As Much a Monument of Remembrance as Any Obelisk
Review:
Powerfully executed from opening scene to credits, this is an exceptionally crafted masterpiece of cinema that speaks to, on every level, Spielberg's utter mastery of his art. There's a haunting dramatic irony that fuels the tension behind each blissfully optimistic moment of ignorant joy, juxtaposed perfectly against scenes of unbridled human horror that never stray into the exploitative or the over-dramatised, but instead tells this tragedy in an unprecedented level of realism that cannot fail to move the very heart.

Title: Masterpiece - The best Spielberg has ever done
Review:
It would have been impossible to make a film like Schindler's List one, or five, or even ten years after the ending of II World War. It is needed to go forward a few decades so people can believe that what happened in Europe on 1940s has been real and it is not an evil fictional story. Spielberg assumes this responsability and has the courage to present us an Holocaust film. And not an average one, but the best of all of them.

Spielberg, one of the most talented directors of all time, is able to leave behind his blockbuster, family-entertaining, adventure style (Jurassic Park, Indiana Jones, Jaws, E. T) to suddenly give us a very graphic, disturbing, yet personal, film about horror, suffering and death, demonstrating his amazing talent. It is, indeed, the best film Spielberg has ever done without any doubt.

The plot is deep and complete, the direction/rythm is fantastic, it is visually amazing, the black and white filter fits perfectly, the cast (shout out to Liam Neeson and Ralph Fiennes) is fresh and flawless and the score by John Williams is a masterpiece (who also leaves behind his leitmotiv style with many instruments to just a very touching, single violin, making the film very intimate and sensitive).

To sum up, for me it is extremely hard to find something wrong in this film, it is overwhelmly easy to start listing how many fantastic things it has, and it is not possible to give it less than a 10/10. If you are a human being, it is mandatory for you to watch this despite of how hard it can be.

These subjects are so dark and heavy, and perhaps no audience is willing to watch such a desperate movie. Spielberg cleverly shows a warmth by describing the story of these two good and evil men.
